container-title: More Suggested Readings Argyris, Chris. Integrating the Individual and the Organization
title: Ph.D
Although it uses the ubiquitous quadrants, this is a fine career management work, looking at experience and environment to determine when it’s time to go (or how to make it better to stay
A prolific writer and preeminent psychologist; this is his work on combining positive team building with individual well-being to create improved performance
The Consultant’s Calling
One of the philosophic books on consulting you should read
Geoff focuses on the philosophy and values of the profession
The Unconscious Conspiracy
The original and still best work by Bennis on leadership, subtitled, Why Leaders Can’t Lead. Everything else he’s done is really a variation of this work’s. “Leaders are made” philosophy
The Changing World of the Executive
One of the master’s two best, the other being The Effective Executive
The Effective Executive
The only person who makes my list twice. This is still a powerful work, and probably his best
A Theory of Leadership Effectiveness
The champion, perhaps, of the contingency theory approach to leadership
The Capitalist Philosophers
An extraordinary set of brief biographies, from Mary Parker Follet to Elton Mayo and Peter Drucker. This has been required reading in my graduate classes
On Leadership
Simply one of the best, most succinct writers on the subject
Organizations
A graduate-level, excellent text. Later versions are probably available
Human Competence

author.literal: Work carried on by Geary Rummler today.

title: Focus on the performer as part of a stimulus-response dynamic
Management and Machiavelli
Enjoyable and lucid discussion of politics and maneuvering in organizational cultures
New Patterns of Management
One of the toughest writers to comprehend; nevertheless his studies on leadership and performance led to some groundbreaking work at the
The Mager Library
If you haven’t read the collected—and insightfully funny—works of Mager, you aren’t educated in this industry
Motivation and Personality
Classic work on hierarchy of needs and human motivation
Human Motivation
Need/achievement theory and connections to Maslow’s work
The Human Side of Enterprise
His classic work on Theory X and Theory Y
The Company Man
A good history of companies, organizations, and the reasons for their current structure

note: Still the authority on process consultation.
title: Process Consultation
Psychology and Industry Today
A graduate-level text that’s clear and coherent. This is the fifth edition, and there is probably a newer one available
Scientific Management
This is a terrific book, by the “first” management consultant. A “must” read if you’re serious about the profession
Million Dollar Consulting: The Professional’s Guide to Building A Practice
Still my best seller after all these years
The Managerial Mystique
One of the most vocal in terms of “leaders are born, not made.” A counterpoint to the work of Bennis
